Entry.0:
DELVAL WOOD

My motto’s while in the army is as follows
Entry.1:
as you are told

Be obliging always

Smile at trouble

Never say die

Think for yourself but never speak them but just wander around and say nothing
Entry.2:
argue for it “aint worth while

MONTABAUN
Entry.3: “Cheerio" this year will see it out & we wont be sorry
Entry.4: Rain, Rain, mud and more mud what a dirty world
Entry.5: Lieut Haigh was wounded this morn bullet pierced his chest
Entry.6:
I am out of a job, spare man

BERNAFAY WOOD
Entry.7: Now I am, cook to the officer’s wonder how I’ll shape
Entry.8: Im no good at cooking a girl’s job and I’m all boy
Entry.9:
Aeroplanes in galore tis a sunny day & I kind of feel happy 

A good week but, all the same it was hard, “ah me"

WATERLOT FARM
Entry.10:
Out in a snow storm a buggar 

I looked like an ice cream
Entry.11: On the road to Albert with a running nose
Entry.12: Rum is horrible stuff, very cheering and makes you forget
Entry.13:
A midnight march to Waterlot Farm

POMMIERS REDOUBT
Entry.14: The boys are on fatigue work laying cables
Entry.15: Camped at Montabaun, not bad but a buggar just the same
Entry.16:
Bernafay Wood at present my goal 

I wish it would clear up

DERNANCOURT
Entry.17: Getting ready to shift; I’d like to shift to Australia
Entry.18: On the road to Dernancourt with a light heart
Entry.19: Now at Meaulte for whisky sure it is a cheerful job
Entry.20:
Cooking again it dont suit me

BEURE
Entry.21: Oh dearie me aint it cold my hair is all icicles
Entry.22: All the ponds are frozen over I slipt on my dignity
Entry.23:
Ice a foot thick in the well and the fire’s out 

Im very dirty and almost afraid to have a wash

MEAULTE
Entry.24: Out punching coal & wood but I got pinched instead
Entry.25: Rissoles, Soup Roast Beef Custard my menu tonight
Entry.26: Blow the cooking I’ll turn it in
Entry.27:
Got another job company groom

BECORDEL
Entry.28: Nutty a big chestnut my charge
Entry.30:
The place is a fairyland snow again 

I am writing home

MAMETZ
Entry.31: Moving to Albert and then to the line
Entry.32: Huns in planes dropped bombs on the town
Entry.33: Scotts Redoubt so theres fight about
Entry.34:
The battalion take over tonight

FRICOURT
Entry.35: La Boiselle in a good dugout
Entry.36: The surroundings are very dismal, old wire broken timber and shell holes
Entry.37:
The front is very quite, the only consolation is the mud 

Jack French my little mate.

LA BOISELLE
Entry.38: The battalion are being releived tonight “oh “Christ “its awful
Entry.39: Sunken Road Sausage Gully & the Chalk Pit are hardy recognisable
Entry.40: Snow & sleet, are me tis a hard old world
Entry.41:
Rum issue cut out, we cant be winning no, we cant be

BAZENTIN
Entry.42: On the road, for whishy & gin
Entry.43: Gunpit & Hot + Rds Acid Drop Camp, horrible places.
Entry.44:
Sunday once again the time passes very Quickly

by joves I’m lousy these chats almost drive you cranky

AUVELUY
Entry.45: Blast the rats like bad women, they torment me
Entry.46:
On picket, tis a lonely job. 

“Valley of Hope
Entry.47: The poor old horses have a hellish time
Entry.48:
On the go all the time, like a fly

CONTALMAISON
Entry.49: A fellow is just a mass of mud
Entry.51:
I’ve just lost my voice again, Im just whispering 

It is a buggar of a war

BECOURT
Entry.52: Making the best of a bad time it is marvellous what we can endure
Entry.53: Acid Drop camp is now our home just a home thats all
Entry.54: Now at what was once upon a time the villiage of CONTALMAISON
Entry.55:
My horse & I are doing good work

CINQUE PORT
Entry.57: Cinque Port Camp is now our station
Entry.58:
It is cold oh 
sold
 so cold 

Long Rides on bad roads

MARTINPUICH
Entry.59: Nothing much doing in the line
Entry.60: A few hun prisoners keep coming in
Entry.61:
The enemys gaol 

birds have abetter time than we do
Entry.62:
My birthday kept it up with a bottle of gin

POZOIERES
Entry.63: Things are brightening up, the artillery is very busy
Entry.64: The sun as made it’s appearence
Entry.65:
The hun is feeling the strain 

So am I. getting weary

LE SARS
Entry.66: A ten mile ride with a case of Whisky
Entry.68: We are having a few casualtys in harrishing the hun, we’ve got him thinking
Entry.69:
The 5th Brigade captured the Buttte of WARLENCOURT

LE BARQUE
Entry.70: By jove the battalion are working hard for six bob a day
Entry.71: Riding with the Colonel to the front line and got lost, nothing extraordinary
Entry.72:
Le Sars smashed to dust & match wood 

Wading through mud knee deep and deeper

WARLENCOURT
Entry.73: Le Barque is now in our hands or a least whats left of it
Entry.74: Also Ligny-Thilloy and Grevilliers both places in ruins
Entry.75: Camped in tents at Martinpuich just a quagmire
Entry.76:
It is a hard life but the boys are sticking it out

LIGNY-THILLOY
Entry.77: Lost my little black pony Tibby
Entry.78:
Early this morning the Australian boys entered Bapume 

Hurrah
Entry.79:
Battalion is back at Fricourt weary and weather beaten 

Horse lines at La Boiselle

GREVILLIERS
Entry.80: Taking things a bit easy but not for long
Entry.81: Advancing to Baupaume “oh" what a scene of confusion
Entry.82: Now in an old Manor House at Biefvilliers
Entry.83:
Outpost duty is now our business & a mighty cold job to

BIEFVILLIERS
Entry.84: The horse have good stables, poor old “Nutty" cant make it out
Entry.85: The wire entanglements about here are hellish, the hun expected to stop
Entry.86:
They have an idea this house is mined but Im going sleep here 

Walking 19 Kilo’s to ALBERT

BEAUGNATRE
Entry.88: On the road back to Baliff Wood
Entry.89: Met a few old friends yesterday
Entry.90:
Camped near Shelter Wood

LOUPART WOOD
Entry.92: A great air fight this morning the hun won, a good go
Entry.93:
Just settling down when along comes the order to move 

B & D Coys on fatigue near Loupart Wood

VAULX
Entry.94:
Nuttys in a good gun pit 

Im in a hun dug out
Entry.95: The scenes about here are gasthly dead everywhere
Entry.97:
Blue Skys & bright sunshine. O K.

NORIUEL
Entry.99: Had a rough night back at Becourt
Entry.100:
Cols as an iced “Ginger beer 

Snowing like “Billeo"

ECOUST
Entry.101: Prepare to move is the order, up the line again
Entry.103:
On my usual tour of the field 

Had rabbit for dinner
Entry.104:
Hungry as a hunter with nothing to eat

FREMICOURT
Entry.105:
Left Fricourt this morning for the front 

BEAUGNATRE
Entry.106:
Last night was a brute raining and I slept in the mud the lads go on tonight 

NOREIUL
Entry.107:
The Battle of Lagnicourt our boys stopped the gigantic attack of 6000 huns, dead germans in galore 

Our casualtys were under 200 thanks to the 20th Batt

FAVRIEUL
Entry.108:
Camped in a tin shed at VAULX 

Met Mick Dunn
Entry.109: Going to water when the hun spotted us and started to shell wounding McKay and three horses, two dead
Entry.110: They are getting very close to my shed with big shells
Entry.111:
The country about here is beautiful grassy plains & wild flowers

BAPAUME
Entry.112:
A visit to Bapaume the town is sadly knocked about 

He still shells it
Entry.113: Riding to Albert in a motor lorry in quest of goods
Entry.114:
Got lost last night at least got drunk and woke up in a strange place 

Shifting further back for the hun as got the range of the horse lines.

BEAUMETZ
Entry.115: Scenes of desolation heaps of misery on the Douai Road
Entry.116:
That almost leads to despair 

Cambria Road
Entry.117:
Dirty cold, tired and hungry 

“Barb wire flat"
Entry.118:
A rain of shrapnel all day

RAINVILLE
Entry.120:
Rehersing a battle behind the lines 

“Sapignes"
Entry.121:
Out all night with the horses along the bloody Scarpe 

Won a race on ROSIE (chestnut pony)

RAINECOURT
Entry.122: Fritz is sending over a lot of duds
Entry.123: The whole division is standing to in case of an attack
Entry.124: The boys went in to night theres something on, for the guns and gunner’s are very busy
Entry.125:
The start of the battle of Bullecourt the artillery set the ball rolling at 3.35 AM

SAPIGNES
Entry.126: “Oh God what a fight the sky is a blaze of fire & the earth tremors, as if in agony
Entry.127:
1st Brigade helps us

The 6th Brigade got their objective early but the 5th are striking it hard but they’ll get there
Entry.128:
Out they come once more truimphant but the cost was heavy especially with our leaders 

365 was the list of killed & wounded 

in the 17th the whole Division avereged the same
Entry.129: Camped in a grassy gully just near Bapaume
Entry.130: We are I believe, going way back for a good rest
Entry.131: Found my pony today She was with the 102 Howizter Bt in the Valley of Guns
Entry.133: All day in the saddle, weary.
Entry.134: On the road the batt is going back toward Fricourt
Entry.135:
Here we are in good huts & out of the danger zone 

Theres no place like home

ALBERT
Entry.136: Rachael a nice girl in Albert very kind. Had a ride to Fremicourt (60. K
Entry.137: Met General Birdwood to day, a great kidder, he is
Entry.138: Good grass & how the horses love it moving at daylight tomorrow
Entry.139:
Last night was spent in Writing home, too to many girls

SENLIS
Entry.140: “Senlis" our first stop moving to morrow we all got full on Champagne
Entry.141: Arrived at Reubempre seems a nice place
Entry.142:
The country side is a perfect picture 

Staying with a dear old lady

PERRIGOT
Entry.144: Now at Perrigot yarning to Adele
Entry.145: The guest of french people at a villiage named Raineville
Entry.146:
On my way to Herrissart

CONTAY
Entry.148: It is just fine rambling among these villiages
Entry.149:
Beleive me the French women are O K 

I still go to church

REUBEMPRE
Entry.150: At an estaminet in Molliens-au-Bois making eyes at Helene
Entry.151: Schooling horses over fences is good sport if you don’t fall
Entry.152: Octavie & Germaine two modest little flappers
Entry.153:
The beer is like sour water, horrid

HERRISART
Entry.154: France a country of love when the sun shines
Entry.155: Leiut Haigh is back Out in the field manuvering, the Brigader Gen present
Entry.156:
Old Nutty jumped well 2nd & 3rd prize 

The french girls are great workers

CARDONETEE
Entry.158: And treating me as if I was a person
Entry.159: Just popping in the meadows with the poppys
Entry.160:
Having a look around Amiens. A gay city nice girls ect

AMIENS
Entry.161:
Had a long walk yesterday fully forty miles 

“Corbie"
Entry.162: Again in Amiens this time with Captain H Ronald
Entry.163:
Slept last night in a double bed eiderdown & white sheets by myself zig zag 

Had my photo taken

WARLOY
Entry.164: Our fancy dress carnival was a huge success
Entry.166: Rebumpre “Adeiu" transport moving to Bapaume Batt entrainging at Puche-Viller tomorrow
Entry.167:
Spring Garden Camp our halt last night in sound of the guns arrived at Bapaume 4 oclock today

BUZINCOURT
Entry.168:
Awakend from a sound sleep by a gas alarm early this morn 

Camped between two hills “Dolce Far Niente"
Entry.169: We are the reserve division. Summer Sun good rations, & beautiful nights. Lifes worth living. Plenty of “baloons about
Entry.170: Not a single shot fired on this front for 48 hours there must be something in the air for tis very unusual, either a calm before the next storm or peace terms in view
Entry.171: Pay day, “Reville was sounded this morning at 7 oclock tis very hot & quite
Entry.172: A daylight gallop to D.H.Q. at Bancourt with Capt Ronald who caught a motor to Bolounge thence to Blighty for 6 month’s
Entry.173: “Glorious Gully" is the name I have goven to our camping ground it lies in the centre of Bapaume. Biefvilliers and Sapignies
Entry.174: Australian mail today I got six letters
Entry.175: Boxing to day as usual I made the crowd laugh with my antic’s
Entry.176: The hun got lively last night our boys were standing to all night, but was’ent needed
Entry.177: We get up at 4 oclock in the morning which is really 3 AM owing to the daylight saving and as we go to bed at nightfall 11 PM tis a long long day, the front is very very quite
Entry.178: A daylight ride to “Achiet Le Grand" with Lieut Small returned via “Bihucourt".
Entry.179: Won a fight last night and then went out on a midnight mission with the two horses, got bushed
Entry.180: As it is now sure tis a grand old war, nothing what so ever doing on this front
Entry.181: Fighting again put up a great go the cheers and laughter of 2000 men was good to hear I won
Entry.182: An awful storm last night, the worst I have ever witnessed the camp was like an inland sea, tents blown to pieces
Entry.183: Won another fight beat an English tommy. Raining like blazes and our tent is like a seive. “Steele Rudd’s platoon"
Entry.184:
At order and discipline mock not whether that of the army or push 

For brumbies well broken are better than thorough breds bred in the bush 

Another hopeless dawn
Entry.185: I suppose my good letters went to the bottom of the sea with the S.S Mongolia
Entry.186: An impressive parade was held to day in memory of Major Gen Holmes who died from wounds received at Messines
Entry.187: Fighting again, I thrive on it I’m as lively as colt & as wirey as whipcourd
Entry.188: Had a yarn to a girl from N S Wales it reminded me of old times
Entry.189: Fought a Tommy last night never got hurt thanks to my little tantalizing feet it is good fun for the boys
Entry.190: I wonder, if the folks at home realize how monotonous this game is, it is very heart aching
Entry.191:
If you want to feel welched and lonely and sad come out here 

It is raining like hell I’m wet through and have nothing dry to put on
Entry.192:
It is cold & miserable 

The Division are out in the field on a big dress rehersal affair
Entry.193: On the road to Beulancourt having a yarn to my old friend Snarky
Entry.194:
A hopeful dawn a cheerful morn 

We will, I think be on the long long trail to Aus before Xmas
Entry.195:
Old Nutty looked as proud as a new papa when decorated yesterday by the “General" with the BLUE RIBBON

HALLOY
Entry.196: Living in hopes and it is not a bad way to live either, I think I will call my first daughter HOPE at least I hope so
Entry.197: The battle front is as quite as a Good Friday A few air fights and an occasional salvo from the artillery thats all
Entry.198:
There’s a stye on my eye, a boil on my arm, chats on my shirt & scorpions in my bed sure its a great war 

Sunday and not a girl for miles around things are not what they use to be, PAY. DAY

HARLETTES
Entry.199: Monday morning once again, and I am broke did it on a full hand aces & threes 111, 33
Entry.200: A rolling stone gathers no moss but “gee" while your rolling it is great, I’ve had a lovely roll
Entry.201: Thinking hard of many things, What will become of us when the strafe is finished
Entry.202:
When we get back home life wont seem just the same & we will find it hard to settle down

WESTBECOURT
Entry.203:
Just a little luck for I won 100 Francs on four king’s 

Off to Amiens in the morning
Entry.204: Now dining at the Grand Hotel De La Paix Amiens some style I can tell you
Entry.205:
A perfect day, just like an Australian spring time, got a new shirt on 

Do I think we are winning well to speak the truth I am buggared if I know

ACQUIN
Entry.206: The boy’s are out on a midnight stunt charging imaginary foes, they won easy
Entry.207: My arm is like a summer sunset for five lovely boils give it a lovely color
Entry.208: Rain again, this old tent of ours is standing it very well
Entry.209:
Had my arm lanced this morning, I have it in a sling but still do my work

WIZERNES
Entry.210: Sunrise on the western front this morning is beautiful, the sky is one blaze of color’s. “Glorious Gully adeiu"
Entry.211: Now camped between between Thiepval & Beaumont-Hamel. Had a swim in the river Ancre at dawn the coldest thing I’ve ever struck
Entry.212:
A.D.C Co’s entrained for the north yesterday, B Co staying behind on railway work weather very hot and the boys dead beat 

Now in the train bound for goodness knows where passed through St Pol Doullens eventually arriving at St Omer and marched to Arques

ST OMER
Entry.213: Now with a lot of huns nearly all them are wearing the iron cross ribbon, a scraggy lot
Entry.214: Retracing old steps marching through Wizernes, met my little fiancée Laura. After a walk of 21 KILOS. “Westbecourt"
Entry.215: Westbecourt a villiage on the back of beyond A long wet ride to Acquin via Harlettes
Entry.216:
Sitting there with Nutty watching the rain making a little river of my bedroom

LYNDE
Entry.217:
A long wet weary walk to the market town of “Lumbres" which is a nice place, pretty girls in pretty robes, make you wish

Saturday 4

A heavy bombardment is now raging, telling the hun that we are stronger than
Entry.219:
It is a hard life but somehow or another you get to like it for it is so changeable 

Two years a soldier and two years since I gave the girl a ring 2 years of queer times

RENESQUE
Entry.220: I have no shirt on cause I washed it this morning, I use to have a lot of shirts once, only got one now
Entry.221: Full marching order with a long road in front of us, Westbecourt was a good home. After a long trip we get to “Renesqure"
Entry.222: Riding a good horse on beautiful road’s, through magnificent country with “Major Holmes" to the old town of “Steenbecque
Entry.223:
Stormy weather, rain in torrents but thank goodness old Nutty & I are under cover

ARQUES
Entry.224: A twilight march through wonderful woodland’s. Our camp by the canal condemned shifting further out
Entry.225: Woke up this morning with “Christ" at the old monastry of “Clairmarais" situated in a dense forest. Raining again
Entry.226:
Living on a farm another such place as Carnsdale the old stables ect recall other day’s and other face’s 

A new week beginning still along way from home 

Just saddled “Nutty" for a long night ride 

Major Fussell off to BR.H.Q

“CLAIRMARAIS"
Entry.227: We will be here for another winter, but it cant be any worse than the last one so we will battle through it
Entry.228: Just as soon as I get some money I’m off to England Having dinner to night on this selection with the cooky & his family.
Entry.229: Pay day. Dinner last night was fine dainty dishes but what they were composed of I know not but if twas frogs I’ll have more
Entry.230:
Rabbit lovely rabbit for tea real Australian rabbit, sure it was great. A lovely meal

“OCHTEZEELE"
Entry.231: Peace floating about but I think it will float over the bulldog as his teeth well in and is not going to let go now
Entry.232: Harvest time in Flander’s Ripe is the golden grain, And within my heart a feeling To be back home again A long route march to Arniques
Entry.233:
An Australian mail in 2 letters for me, Els & Mue I wrote a little article of prose and sent it to the editor of “Blighty" 

Down on the farm making butter and doing a bit of haymaking

Staple
Entry.234: The hun, in planes was over this way last night dropping bombs not much damage done
Entry.235: To St Omer with Lt. Maynard in this town there are girls of the woman’s army, poor little English girls, at the mercy of the troop’s
Entry.236: A perfect day, bright sunshine and blue sky’s, spent by me in farm labour, just like being at home
Entry.237: Not yet one & washing done, but it was hard work for Madam kept me at it all the time
Entry.238: Here we are arguing the point over girl’s, but it is a very difficult subject, I love all good girl’s but Bill wont have it
Entry.239: I do not think that I will leave this place for it is the best I’ve yet came across since leaving Carnsdale. Visiting “St Omer"
Entry.240:
Just had a good dinner Roast Beef carrots and turnips followed by Pheasant, potatoes and seasoned sauce and beautiful beer 

The 17th batt, picked by General Birdwood as the crack regiment and chosen to lead the Anzacs in the review by “F.M.Haig"
Entry.241: A parcel from Dad which I shared with the folk of the good farm 'Clarmary’. Very wet day.
Entry.242: A letter from Emma The mail of late as been coming very slowly but I suppose the hun as sank some mail boats
Entry.243: The Division reviewed to day by the Com. In Chief of the British Army Sir Douglas Haig. The 17th Batt won his confidence
Entry.244: A great boy for boils twelve week of them & still got two to keep me company
Entry.245: Nothing much doing just fooling round, the birds practising wood fighting ect, it is not such a bad war when back here
Entry.246: Pay day, 20 F a fortnight a promenade a drop of fire water tin of fags and a post card or 2 and then “finee" – broke
Entry.247:
A beautiful moonlight night but yonder sky is ablaze with gun fire and the roar of the guns is awful 

Overhead planes of the hun may be seen in the flashes of the searchlights and the explosion of their bombs is hellish, the place is shaking like a jelly
Entry.248: A great battle is raging troops running to and fro. All night long I have been listening to the fierce bombardment
Entry.249: A glorious day with a lull on the battle front not a sound to be heard, excepting a tune “Dixie", from the band
Entry.250:
Basking in the sun with a stook of hay for a pillow, my thoughts are good and my mind content

Thursday 6

They are fighting like hell, the big guns are roaring unceasingly “Ah" it is cruel.

Friday 7

Batt. Parade competition C Coy 1st B. Coy 2nd D Coy 3rd A coy
Entry.251: A good contest B just beaten by 2 points
Entry.252: Brigade Parade competition was won by the
Entry.253: Batt with the 19th second. I spent a good day in St Omer
Entry.254:
A nice bright Sunday just the kind of day that a chap would give a year of his life to spend at home 

NOTES Franc notes are very scarce and NOTES, £1 notes are a thing of the past

SWAN CHATEAU
Entry.255: Getting ready to go into action a big hop over, I beleive is our mission The battalion is out on its final practice.
Entry.256: Reville this morning at three oclock and then a starlight march to the parade ground for field manoeuvre’s
Entry.257: The way was long, we left Claumarais at 8, passed through Staple Hardajem & Castra arriving at Winnzelle just at nightfall. Going into action
Entry.258:
Aroused at 4 this morning fell in a 5,30 marched through Steenvoorde & Arbelle to Renilhest. 50 KILO’S in 2 days and we are loaded like camel’s

BELGIAN BATTERY. CR
Entry.259: Now in the “Valley of Confusion" (near Ypres), guns men horses motors wagons & trains, going and coming like a huge ant bed, the front was quiet
Entry.260: It is a wonderful war and to folks who have never been in war zones it is beyond realisation “Ah" me it is bewildering
Entry.261:
On our right a heavy artillery duel, above us a fleet of german planes who are dropping bombs and all around us machine guns are firing the din is terrifying Oh what a Sunday

BRISTOL. FARM
Entry.262: If the rain keeps off this week will be one of the wildest weeks in history. Guns and munitions haunt me
Entry.263: Three oclock in the morn I am on picket, horses very quiet but the front line one blaze of fire and the fight as just began
Entry.264:
The Batt. go into the fray tonight which will be the greatest battle of the war 

God be with them and lead them to “Victory"
Entry.265:
It would have broken Germanys heart, if they’d have seen our boys marching into action singing & laughing like school boy’s

GLENCORSE WOOD
Entry.266: The great battle over our boys triumphed right along the line. Lt Haigh wounded twice, we lost good men, it is wicked
Entry.267:
This battle was the 6 Brig greatest victory yet achieved by the Anzac’s 

Battalion releived last night, now at Ypres
Entry.268:
Left Ypres at 4 this morn and marched to Halifax camp near “Vlaamantinghe Our casualties numbered about 250. The sights witnessed in a day on the field, are awful blood and iron, pain and suffering

POPERINGHE
Entry.269: On the move, again got up at 3 and rode to Winnipeg camp and then marched to Wickenham living in tents, nice day
Entry.270: Hopping about in the hop field’s. Lt Allan Doig is now Nuttys pilot and O.C. at B. Company Visiting Poperinghe.
Entry.271: Waiting patiently for money from home so as I can go to England This is my 567th day of A.S a long stretch
Entry.272:
Moonlight on the battle fields of Belgium “ah to be back at Carnsdale a night like this would be soothe a soldiers mind

MENIN GATE
Entry.273: Just preparing for a good night when along comes the order to move going up the line, We rested for the night at “La. Chytes"
Entry.274: “Batt", reserve battalion doing fatigue work now camped alongside the moat of “Ypres" the old town is leveled almost to ground
Entry.275:
An awful night, heavy fighting, the artillerys roar was terrific and the explosion of aeriel torpedo’s deadly, many horses killed 

A lovely day perfect by the will of God but by the will of man it is hellish and heartbreaking 

LILLE GATE
Entry.276: The fighting is harder than ever, every gun in the army’s seems to be on this front, the casualtys are few consd.
Entry.277:
I feel well & strong but the least shock or excitement makes me tremble, “ah" well a chap cant go on forever

Wednesday 3

Tomorrow at dawn the 1st 2nd &
Entry.278: Div’s of Australians go over the parapet, may good luck go with them
Entry.279:
4

Over they went and met with great sucess 4000 prisoner’s and much booty, good work

OUDERDOM.
Entry.280: Winter’s first appearence cold winds heavy rain and of course mud. Tonight the 5th Brig. releive the
Entry.281:
Brigade

Saturday 6

Sleeping in a pool of water for the rain as submerged my dwelling, “ah" it’s awful but it’s got to be done
Entry.282:
Sunday 7th, and so far the worst day I have experienced in my life. For we packed the rations on horses & led them to Anzac House through mud waist high and blinding rain and shell fire

CAFE BELGE
Entry.283: The best bad day of my career, stranded with four jars of RUM at ZOWNEBEKE standing in mud, that covered my bosom,
Entry.284:
but despite the severe trial, I cursed as a bush bred boy can curse, and 
then
 I laughed like hell
Entry.285: The 17th & 20th Batts charged the huns yesterday, but after getting their object they retired Releived by the 45th Batt
Entry.286:
A lot of good men gone. Jack Lyons Mr New Andy Kear, and many more. Will it never end

KIT AND KAT
Entry.287: Shifting out of Ypres left by train got off at Abelle & marched to the frontier of France & Belgium, resting at a farm
Entry.288: Drinking the blue’s away “Vin Rouge Vin Blange Beer ect. Had a wash & shave the first for ten day’s
Entry.289:
Still drinking. Old Nutty is a complete wreck. All the boys are “fou the nou but it is a case of drink and forget The sun is shining and life is a good deal better.

WINNIZEELE
Entry.290: Just been through the dead mens mail it is bad enough for us, but to the folks at home “Oh what anguish
Entry.291: Had a clean change of clothes, and parted with my little shirt that I’ve worn for four months
Entry.292: On a visit to the villiage of Winnizelle. A lot of the old boys have rejoined the battalion. Posted Xmas cards
Entry.293:
730 days of soldiering 2 long year’s of life days of anxiety nights of fun, a queer mixture still going strong

STEENVOORDE
Entry.294: I am lousey these billets are alive with vermin, just had a chat, caught fifty five
Entry.295: Good things come to those who wait a good job offered me on the Divisional staff but the O.C (Mj.H) wouldent hear of it
Entry.296:
Heavy Artillery fire on the front evidently a barage being sent over prior to a big attack, it makes me sigh

A bright blue Sunday “Ah" I wish it would end for I am sick homesick. AUSTRALIA

CASSELL
Entry.297: An Australian mail in, I got 2 one from Muriel a good letter & one from the bank good also
Entry.298: The weather is getting colder every day, but never the less it as commenced more favourably than last year
Entry.299:
I think we are winning good news in today

Down on the Somme we knocked Fritz pretty hard
Entry.300:
Birdwood, General of the A.I.F was here to day and gave the boys their medal’s

PASCHEN-DALE
Entry.301: A cold bleak wet day, and we are going back into action, being conveyed to forward area by motor lorrie’s
Entry.302: A long wet ride and then we arrived at S.I.Helle (Dickiebusch), a fierce battle raging. Camped in tents mud & slush, very very cold
Entry.303:
A heavy frost. On the move again. The guns still keep thundering but our gains are little “Ah" me its a B- 

The sun goes down in a flame of gold the mists rise up “Ah God" so cold. Camped in mi-mi’s on the fringe of “Desolation

Zillebeke
Entry.304: Bombs falling all around us was bad enough but when a big shell lifted us out of our beds, ‘Oh it was topping
Entry.305: Buggar the army and buggar the war, that is the spirit of the British Army right along the battle front
Entry.306: Got mixed up with men from the U.S.A. and of course I am guessing and kalkerlating all kinds of things
Entry.307:
A bomb fell outside my tent, made a big row, woke me up and made a seive of my tent “Lucky Jack"

Zonnebeke
Entry.308: Batt go into the line today, releiving the 7th Brigade, front trench a water hole
Entry.309: RUM marvellous stuff has soothing as an old time melody where there’s danger about Doing a lot of buisness
Entry.310:
Rations to Garter Point heavy shelling, my old steed blown over with concussion, self half mad with fear, we got through with one casualty George OLeary had a leg broken

Steenvorde
Entry.311: Canadians went over this morning and met with success casualtys very light
Entry.312: A ride for life through a wall of fire on Westhoek Ridge, thank the Lord we came through unscathed
Entry.313: Batt releived today resting until morn at the “Half Way House" on the Menin Road
Entry.314:
On the move, but it is out of the fray so we are happy. Arrived at a farm near Steenvoorde at dusk

CALAIS
Entry.315: At last, I report to B.H.Q for leave to the United Kingdom my destination is “The land of the Shamrock
Entry.316: Left Godesvalle at 2 this morning arrived at Calais at 6, camped in tents, awaiting a boat and its very cold
Entry.317:
Left Calais by the S.S Dieppe at 8 arrived at Dover by 10 and London was reached by 1 (one) 

London is very quite The Trip across was rough almost everyone sick, I was not ill

LONDON
Entry.318: Swanking around the Strand Picadilly & Leict. Square Leaving for Ireland tonight Via Scotland by the G.N.W Railway
Entry.319: Arrived at Strangaer (Scotland) at daybreak boarded the S.S Princess Maud, arriving at Larnde (Ireland) for dinner
Entry.320: Now in Coleraine ah it is good and very nice to hear the Irish Colleens say “Jackie"
Entry.321:
At an Irish part “och sure it was grand pretty wee lassie och I am in love getting

ERIN GO BRACH
Entry.322: Visiting Port Stewart a wee watering plaace something after the style of La Perouse
Entry.323: The folks of Ireland are very good, they cannot do enough to make my stay happy
Entry.324:
Ballygallon the farm of Mr J ONiell 

Portrush a fine seaside resort 

Bushmills a typical Irish town 

River Boinn a fine stream

GIANTS CAUSEWAY
Entry.325: Giants Causeway a wonderful place it would seem that it was built by a master builder
Entry.326: Dunluce Castle a place with a great history – built on the edge of a great cliff
Entry.327: A great night in a great room full of wee girls Moira Sheila Beth Norah & Kathleen
Entry.328:
Drumslade an Irish farm the scene tonight of an Irish spree Och its funny

Belfast
Entry.329: A good night at the home of Mr & Mrs Given “Salmon Leap Castle Rock". I had a nasty fall very shaky
Entry.330: Irish girls are just the sweetest little things imaginable dainty modest and as fresh as the dawn
Entry.331:
At church good little boy and all that but it “aint" the sermon that interest me it is that fair headed and blue eyed daughter of “Eve with the smile of a Angel 

Ports all closed

Bushmills
Entry.332: Coleraine, it is hard to leave you treated me like a toff
Entry.333: Now in the city of Belfast staying with the Miss Millers of Unnersely Avenue, nice girls
Entry.334: Met a little Aust nurse, a dear little girl but she is married. Port closed Sister Caddoux
Entry.335:
Arrived at Dublin for tea fine city but not as good as Belfast 

Ports still closed

Dublin
Entry.336: Left Dublin by the T.S.S Greenore, and “oh what a trip rough very rough
Entry.337: Arrived in London at ten met a couple of Australian civilians who gave me an outing
Entry.338:
London “ta ta" now in the train bound for Dover where we arrived for dinner 

Port of Dover is closed, so we are staying for the night

Dover
Entry.339: Marched to wharf and boarded the S.S Villa De Leigh but after waiting an hour, the port was closed
Entry.340: Spent a good day in Dover a very nice place. Left for home (France) Arrived at Calais for dinner
Entry.341: Stopped at Calais for the night which was severly bombed by the enemy
Entry.342:
After a ride of six hours in the train we got to Castre and then motored to Steenwurk

Castre
Entry.343: Back with the battalion tis good to renew the acquaintence of the boys.
Entry.344: Menegatte Camp a good home, the front is very quite and the weather very nice
Entry.345:
Running very hard so I will renew, in an hour or two my acquaintence with the MUD 

I just cant helping thinking of dear old Ireland, but it seems so far away

Steenwerk
Entry.346: 6 Gotha’s over today and dropped bombs round about the camp
Entry.347: Got a new horse that is owned by the Padre, I gave him the name of “Sky Pilot
Entry.348: The final for the Brigade Shield was won by the 17th Batt 3 to nil of the 5th FA
Entry.349:
Voted today on the conscription question. Guess how I voted

Neuve Eglise
Entry.350: A long ride to Ravelcourt with A/Adjudant Gilbert for money. Pay day
Entry.351: Battalion moving into action releiving the 33rd Batt, on the sector right of Messines
Entry.352:
Transport in good quarters at the town of Pont-Neippe 

First snow of the year so far the winter is a lot better than last year

Doudou
Entry.353: Nothing much on the fighting line on this sector, but I have an idea that it will liven up
Entry.354: Moon dear don’t shine to soon dear for when you shine the hun gets busy with his bombs
Entry.355: Doudou Dump and Rossignol Camp. So far the coldest day of the year
Entry.356:
Camped in a very nice little hut but it is cold

Pont de Nieppe
Entry.357: On picket, the place presents a beautiful appearance covered with flakes of snow
Entry.358: Visited the town of Neuve-Eglise and met many old pals. F Bolton H Freyer & T Cowan
Entry.359:
This day last year it was hard, we were battling with the mud along the Somme. 

This day is so good and fine that it seems almost a new country, to last year

Neippe
Entry.360:
Met Bob Cox of Botany I have no recollection of Xmas Eve Nutty brought me home from the D.A.C

Tuesday 25
Entry.361: at Stuff camp was a trifle damp, but 1000 times better than 1916
Entry.362: A heavy fall of snow and a full moon good for the planes but they are very quite
Entry.363:
The front is so good that it is hard to realize that a war is on at all.

Bailliue
Entry.364: Tom Livermore and I are living like we never lived, since leaving home, dainty meals & good beds “Ville De Grand"
Entry.365: A ride to Bailleu took “Sky Pilot" to the Veterinary Hospital Roads like glass
Entry.366:
The last Sunday of a year that was good, of a year that was hard, Delval Wood Malt Trench Loupart Wd Le Sars Lagnicourt Noreuil, Bullecourt Clairmarias Glencorse Passchendaele, all hard but still we live.

Romarin

Monday 31

The year is past may it be the last of war Au Revior “17" worse you could have been
Entry.367: The Sun is rising, the dawn is hopeful 1918 may you be kind. Welcome in
Entry.368: This year according to the papers like last year is a year of Victory “Ah me the poor public
Entry.369:
No mail for weeks and weeks and week. Bread issue per man per day is 3 Ozs, looks as if we are winning

Brune Gaye
Entry.370: Brune Gaye Camp Romarin Rossignol we shifted to this place yesterday
Entry.371: A long ride to the big town of Bailleeul with Capt Manifield O.C of B Coy
Entry.372:
What does a soldier do in his spare time First he writes a letter home and then he gets as full as an egg on wine 

A day of prayer but I’ve lost faith in the Church and its lessons but Ill plod along with a good spirit

Rossignol
Entry.373: Snow and sleet, and other damn things I have not had a bath for seven weeks
Entry.374: Battalion taking over tonight from the 20th. Peace tearms floating about they make us anxious
Entry.375: A big rumor going round about a big naval battle, with the result in our favour
Entry.376: Another diary finished and I am hoping to be home before another one is ended
